meanings.definition: A sudden brief burst of bright flame or light.
meanings.sent1: The fireworks display ended with a colorful flare in the sky.
meanings.sent2: The flare of the match illuminated the dark room.
meanings.sent3: The chef's dramatic flare with the torch made everyone gasp.
meanings.sent4: Her laughter was like a flare, bright and infectious.
meanings.sent5: The flare of the lighthouse guided ships safely to shore.

meanings.definition: A sudden burst of intense emotion or activity.
meanings.sent1: The sudden flare of anger in his eyes startled me.
meanings.sent2: The flare of excitement in the crowd was palpable.
meanings.sent3: Her flare of enthusiasm for the project was contagious.
meanings.sent4: The news of the victory caused a flare of celebration in the town.
meanings.sent5: The flare of panic spread quickly through the group.

meanings.definition: To burn with a sudden intensity.
meanings.sent1: The dry leaves began to flare up when the match touched them.
meanings.sent2: The fire started to flare as more wood was added to it.
meanings.sent3: His attempt to cook dinner caused the kitchen to flare up in flames.
meanings.sent4: Emotions can flare up unexpectedly in heated arguments.
meanings.sent5: The candles began to flare brightly in the dark room.

meanings.definition: To become wider at one end.
meanings.sent1: The pants flare out at the bottom, creating a bell-bottom style.
meanings.sent2: The skirt flares at the hips, giving it a flattering silhouette.
meanings.sent3: The tree's roots flare out at the base for stability.
meanings.sent4: The road flares out into a wide intersection ahead.
meanings.sent5: The trumpet's bell flares beautifully as the musician plays.
